üé≠ How to Create a Reaction Roles Preview

Learn how to create a polished preview image showing how reaction roles work in Discord.

1
Set Up Your Discord Server

Create or use a test Discord server where you can demonstrate the feature.

  • Make sure SPIDEY BOT is invited to the server
  • Create a dedicated channel like #demo or #preview
  • Configure reaction roles in the bot dashboard
üí° Use a test server to avoid cluttering your main server

2
Create the Reaction Role Message

In your test channel, have the bot post a message with emojis for role selection.

The message should show:

  • A clear title (e.g., "Choose Your Roles")
  • Description of what each emoji does
  • Multiple emoji reactions for users to click
üí° Make it visually clear and easy to understand

3
Take a Clean Screenshot

Use your Discord client to screenshot the message with reactions:

  • Windows: Snipping Tool or Win+Shift+S
  • Mac: Cmd+Shift+4 or Screenshot app
  • Linux: Flameshot or Gnome Screenshot

Capture:

  • The full message with emoji reactions visible
  • A portion of the chat showing the context
  • Member interactions clicking the emojis

4
Edit & Enhance the Image

Use an image editor to polish your screenshot:

  • Crop: Remove unnecessary UI elements
  • Resize: Make it 600x400px or similar for cards
  • Enhance: Increase contrast or brightness if needed
  • Add Label: Optional text overlay like "Reaction Roles Demo"

Recommended tools:

  • Photoshop / GIMP (free)
  • Canva (online, easy)
  • Paint.NET (simple, lightweight)

5
Optimize File Size

Compress the image for web use:

Use online tools like:
- TinyPNG.com
- Compressor.io
- ImageOptim (Mac)

Target: Keep under 500KB for fast loading

6
Upload to Your Website

Store the image in your project:

/public/assets/reaction-roles-preview.png

Then reference it in your HTML:

<img src="/assets/reaction-roles-preview.png" alt="Reaction Roles Preview">
üí° Keep all preview images in the /public/assets folder

7
Update Card HTML

Replace the placeholder preview with your actual image:

<div style="background: url('/assets/reaction-roles-preview.png'); background-size: cover; height: 180px;"></div>

Or use an img tag for better compatibility:

<img src="/assets/reaction-roles-preview.png" style="width: 100%; height: 180px; object-fit: cover;">
üí° Use object-fit: cover to maintain aspect ratio

8
Test & Iterate

View your card on the website and verify:

  • Image displays correctly on desktop and mobile
  • Image quality is sharp and clear
  • Text is readable and prominent
  • File loads quickly

If needed, go back to step 4 and refine the image.
